Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Cybersecurity researchers have tracked the Conspirators and their malicious activity using the labels “Sandworm Team,” “Telebots,” “Voodoo Bear,” and “Iron Viking.”
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The charges were announced by Assistant Attorney General John C. Demers; FBI Deputy Director David Bowdich; U.S. Attorney for the Western District of Pennsylvania Scott W. Brady; and Special Agents in Charge of the FBI’s Atlanta, Oklahoma City, and Pittsburgh Field Offices, J.C. “Chris” Hacker, Melissa R. Godbold, and Michael A. Christman, respectively.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “No country has weaponized its cyber capabilities as maliciously or irresponsibly as Russia, wantonly causing unprecedented damage to pursue small tactical advantages and to satisfy fits of spite,” said Assistant Attorney General for National Security John C. Demers.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “Today the department has charged these Russian officers with conducting the most disruptive and destructive series of computer attacks ever attributed to a single group, including by unleashing the NotPetya malware.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: No nation will recapture greatness while behaving in this way.”
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “The FBI has repeatedly warned that Russia is a highly capable cyber adversary, and the information revealed in this indictment illustrates how pervasive and destructive Russia’s cyber activities truly are,” said FBI Deputy Director David Bowdich.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “But this indictment also highlights the FBI’s capabilities.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: We have the tools to investigate these malicious malware attacks, identify the perpetrators, and then impose risks and consequences on them.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: As demonstrated today, we will relentlessly pursue those who threaten the United States and its citizens.”
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “For more than two years we have worked tirelessly to expose these Russian GRU Officers who engaged in a global campaign of hacking, disruption and destabilization, representing the most destructive and costly cyber-attacks in history,” said U.S. Attorney Scott W. Brady for the Western District of Pennsylvania.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “The crimes committed by Russian government officials were against real victims who suffered real harm.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: We have an obligation to hold accountable those who commit crimes – no matter where they reside and no matter for whom they work – in order to seek justice on behalf of these victims.”
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “The exceptional talent and dedication of our teams in Pittsburgh, Atlanta and Oklahoma City who spent years tracking these members of the GRU is unmatched,” said FBI Pittsburgh Special Agent in Charge Michael A. Christman.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: “These criminals underestimated the power of shared intelligence, resources and expertise through law enforcement, private sector and international partnerships.”
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The defendants, Yuriy Sergeyevich Andrienko (Юрий Сергеевич Андриенко), 32; Sergey Vladimirovich Detistov (Сергей Владимирович Детистов), 35; Pavel Valeryevich Frolov (Павел Валерьевич Фролов), 28; Anatoliy Sergeyevich Kovalev (Анатолий Сергеевич Ковалев), 29; Artem Valeryevich Ochichenko (Артем Валерьевич Очиченко), 27; and Petr Nikolayevich Pliskin (Петр Николаевич Плискин), 32, are all charged in seven counts: conspiracy to conduct computer fraud and abuse, conspiracy to commit wire fraud, wire fraud, damaging protected computers, and aggravated identity theft.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Each defendant is charged in every count.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The charges contained in the indictment are merely accusations, however, and the defendants are presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty beyond a reasonable doubt.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
The indictment accuses each defendant of committing the following overt acts in furtherance of the charged crimes:




Defendant


Summary of Overt Acts




Yuriy Sergeyevich Andrienko


·      Developed components of the NotPetya and Olympic Destroyer malware.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
Sergey Vladimirovich Detistov


·      Developed components of the NotPetya malware; and
·      Prepared spearphishing campaigns targeting the 2018 PyeongChang Winter Olympic Games.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
Pavel Valeryevich Frolov


·       Developed components of the KillDisk and NotPetya malware.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
Anatoliy Sergeyevich Kovalev


·       Developed spearphishing techniques and messages used to target:
-       En Marche!
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
Artem Valeryevich Ochichenko


·       Participated in spearphishing campaigns targeting 2018 PyeongChang Winter Olympic Games partners; and
·       Conducted technical reconnaissance of the Parliament of Georgia official domain and attempted to gain unauthorized access to its network.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text:
Petr Nikolayevich Pliskin


·       Developed components of the NotPetya and Olympic Destroyer malware.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The defendants and their co-conspirators caused damage and disruption to computer networks worldwide, including in France, Georgia, the Netherlands, Republic of Korea, Ukraine, the United Kingdom, and the United States.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The NotPetya malware, for example, spread worldwide, damaged computers used in critical infrastructure, and caused enormous financial losses.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Those losses were only part of the harm, however.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: For example, the NotPetya malware impaired Heritage Valley’s provision of critical medical services to citizens of the Western District of Pennsylvania through its two hospitals, 60 offices, and 18 community satellite facilities.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The attack caused the unavailability of patient lists, patient history, physical examination files, and laboratory records.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Heritage Valley lost access to its mission-critical computer systems (such as those relating to cardiology, nuclear medicine, radiology, and surgery) for approximately one week and administrative computer systems for almost one month, thereby causing a threat to public health and safety.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The conspiracy to commit computer fraud and abuse carries a maximum sentence of five years in prison; conspiracy to commit wire fraud carries a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison; the two counts of wire fraud carry a maximum sentence of 20 years in prison; intentional damage to a protected computer carries a maximum sentence of 10 years in prison; and the two counts of aggravated identity theft carry a mandatory sentence of two years in prison.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The indictment also alleges false registration of domain names, which would increase the maximum sentence of imprisonment for wire fraud to 27 years in prison; the maximum sentence of imprisonment for intentional damage to a protected computer to 17 years in prison; and the mandatory sentence of imprisonment for aggravated identity theft to four years in prison.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: These maximum potential sentences are prescribed by Congress, however, and are provided here for informational purposes only, as the assigned judge will determine any sentence of a defendant.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Defendant Kovalev was previously charged in federal indictment number CR 18-215, in the District of Columbia, with conspiring to gain unauthorized access into the computers of U.S. persons and entities involved in the administration of the 2016 U.S. elections.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Trial Attorney Heather Alpino and Deputy Chief Sean Newell of the National Security Division’s Counterintelligence and Export Control Section and Assistant U.S. Attorneys Charles Eberle and Jessica Smolar of the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Western District of Pennsylvania are prosecuting this case.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The FBI’s Atlanta, Oklahoma City, and Pittsburgh field offices conducted the investigation, with the assistance of the FBI’s Cyber Division.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The Criminal Division’s Office of International Affairs provided critical assistance in this case.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The department also appreciates the significant cooperation and assistance provided by Ukrainian authorities, the Governments of the Republic of Korea and New Zealand, Georgian authorities, and the United Kingdom’s intelligence services, as well as many of the FBI’s Legal Attachés and other foreign authorities around the world.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Numerous victims cooperated and provided valuable assistance in the investigation.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: The department is also grateful to Google, including its Threat Analysis Group (TAG); Cisco, including its Talos Intelligence Group; Facebook; and Twitter, for the assistance they provided in this investigation.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

text: Some private sector companies independently disabled numerous accounts for violations of the companies’ terms of service.
source: Office of Public Affairs _ Six Russian GRU Officers Charged in Connection with Worldwide Deployment of Destructive Malware and Other Disruptive Actions in Cyberspace _ United States Department of Justice.html

ExPetr/Petya/NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware 

Incidents

28 Jun 2017

 1 minute read								








 

Authors




Anton Ivanov




Orkhan Mamedov





After an analysis of the encryption routine of the malware used in the Petya/ExPetr attacks, we have thought that the threat actor cannot decrypt victims’ disk, even if a payment was made.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: This supports the theory that this malware campaign was not designed as a ransomware attack for financial gain.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: Instead, it appears it was designed as a wiper pretending to be ransomware.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: Below the technical details are presented.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text:
First, in order to decrypt victim’s disk the attackers need the installation ID:

In previous versions of “similar” ransomware like Petya/Mischa/GoldenEye, this installation ID contains crucial information for the key recovery.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: After sending this information to the attacker they can extract the decryption key using their private key.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text:
Here’s how this installation ID is generated in the ExPetr ransomware:

This installation ID in our test case is built using the CryptGenRandom function, which is basically generating random data.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text:
The following buffer contains the randomly generated data in an encoded “BASE58” format:

If we compare this randomly generated data and the final installation ID shown in the first screen,  they are the same.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: In a normal setup, this string should contain encrypted information that will be used to restore the decryption key.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: For ExPetr, the ID shown in the ransom screen is just plain random data.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: That means that the attacker cannot extract any decryption information from such a randomly generated string displayed on the victim, and as a result, the victims will not be able to decrypt any of the encrypted disks using the installation ID.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: What does it mean?
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: Well, first of all, this is the worst-case news for the victims – even if they pay the ransom they will not get their data back.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: Secondly, this reinforces the theory that the main goal of the ExPetr attack was not financially motivated, but destructive.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

text: Our friend Matt Suiche from Comae Technologies independently came to the same conclusion.
source: ExPetr_Petya_NotPetya is a Wiper, Not Ransomware _ Securelist.html

Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics


By 
Warren Mercer



            Monday, February 12, 2018 08:16
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This blog post is authored by Warren Mercer and Paul Rascagneres.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Ben Baker and Matthew Molyett contributed to this post.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Update 2/13 08:30 We have updated the information regarding the use of stolen credentialsUpdate 2/12 12:00:
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: We have updated the destructor section with action taken against mapped file sharesSummary The Winter Olympics this year is being held in Pyeongchang, South Korea.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The Guardian, a UK Newspaper reported an article that suggested the Olympic computer systems suffered technical issues during the opening ceremony.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Officials at the games confirmed some technical issues to non-critical systems and they completed recovery within around 12 hours.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Sunday 11th February the Olympic games officials confirmed a cyber attack occurred but did not comment or speculate further.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Talos have identified the samples, with moderate confidence, used in this attack.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The infection vector is currently unknown as we continue to investigate.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The samples identified, however, are not from adversaries looking for information from the games but instead they are aimed to disrupt the games.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The samples analysed appear to perform only destructive functionality.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: There does not appear to be any exfiltration of data.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Analysis shows that actors are again favouring legitimate pieces of software as PsExec functionality is identified within the sample.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The destructive nature of this malware aims to render the machine unusable by deleting shadow copies, event logs and trying to use PsExec & WMI to further move through the environment.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This is something we have witnessed previously with BadRabbit and Nyetya.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Olympic Destroyer Workflow Initial stage The initial edb1ff2521fb4bf748111f92786d260d40407a2e8463dcd24bb09f908ee13eb9 sample is a binary that, when executed, drops multiple files on to the victim host.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: These files are embedded as resources (obfuscated).
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: These files are named using randomly generated file names, however, the hashes of the file when written to disk is the same during our analysis on multiple instances.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Currently we are not aware of the initial infection vector used.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This could have been delivered in a multitude of ways as it is simply a binary file.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Two of the dropped files (the stealing modules) are executed with 2 arguments: 123 and a named pipe.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The named pipe is used as a communication channel between the initial stage and the dropped executable.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The technique was used during BadRabbit & Nyetya.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The initial stage is responsible for propagation.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The network discovery is performed using two techniques:By checking the ARP table with the Windows API GetIPNetTable;By WMI (using WQL) with the following request: "SELECT ds_cn FROM ds_computer".
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This request attempts to list all the systems within the current environment/directory.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The network propagation is performed using PsExec and WMI (via the Win32_Process class).
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Here is the code executed remotely:The purpose is to copy the initial stage to the remote system in %ProgramData%\%COMPUTERNAME%.exe and to execute it via a VBScript.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: To perform the lateral movement, the malware needs credentials, it uses 2 stealers described in the next section:The credentials have not been hardcoded into the binary by the attackers themselves.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The malware dynamically updates this list after using the password stealers.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: A new version of the binary is generated with the newly discovered credentials.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This new binary will be used on the new infected systems via the propagation.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This feature explains why we discovered several samples with different sets of credentials that were collected from previously infected systems.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: As you can see, the domain attempted to be used is related to Pyeongchang 2018.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: We identified 44 individual accounts in the binary.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Dropped Files Browser Credential Stealer Olympic Destroyer drops a browser credential stealer.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The final payload is embedded in an obfuscated resource.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: To be executed, the sample must have 2 arguments as mentioned previously.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The stealer supports: Internet Explorer, Firefox and Chrome.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The malware parses the registry and it queries the sqlite file in order to retrieve stored credentials.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: SQLite is embedded in the sample:System Credential Stealer In additional to the browsers credential stealer, Olympic Destroyer drops and executes a system stealer.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The stealer attempts to obtain credentials from LSASS with a technique similar to that used by Mimikatz.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Here is the output format parsed by the initial stage:
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Destructor The destructive portion of this malware starts during initial execution on the victim machine.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The initial malware execution results in multiple files written to disk, as discussed.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Following this, the malware then continues on it's path by beginning the malicious destruction element.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: By leveraging cmd.exe from the host the malware first deletes all possible shadow copies on the system using vssadmin:C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c c:\Windows\system32\vssadmin.exe delete shadows /all
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: /quietNext, again leveraging cmd.exe execution on the host we can see the author using wbadmin.exe, for those not familiar with wbadmin, this is the replacement for ntbackup on modern operating systems.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: wbadmin.exe delete catalog -quietThis step is executed to ensure that file recovery is not trivial - WBAdmin can be used to recover individual files, folders and also whole drives so this would be a very convenient tool for a sysadmin to use in order to aid recovery.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The next step the attacker takes in this destructive path is to, again leverage cmd.exe, but this time use bcdedit, a tool used for boot config data information, to ensure that the Windows recovery console does not attempt to repair anything on the host.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: bcdedit.exe /set {default} bootstatuspolicy ignoreallfailures & bcdedit /set {default} recoveryenabled noThe attacker has now attempted to ensure that recovery is extremely difficult for any impacted hosts and to further cover their tracks the deletion of the System & Security windows event log is performed, this will be used to try and make any analysis more difficult.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text:
wevtutil.exe cl System

C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /c wevtutil.exe cl
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: SecurityWiping all available methods of recovery shows this attacker had no intention of leaving the machine useable.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The purpose of this malware is to perform destruction of the host, leave the computer system offline, and wipe remote data.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Additionally, the destroyer disables all the services on the system:The malware uses the ChangeServiceConfigW API to change the start type to 4 which means: "Disabled: Specifies that the service should not be started.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: "Additionally, the malware lists mapped file shares and for each share, it will wipe the writable files (using either uninitialized data or 0x00
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: depending of the file size).
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Finally after modifying all the system configuration, the destroyer shutdowns the compromised system.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Legitimate FileAdditionally, the Olympic Destroyer drops the legitimate, digitally signed, PsExec file in order to perform lateral movement by using this legitimate tool from Microsoft.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This is another example of an attacker leveraging legitimate tools within their arsenal.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Using legitimate tools like PsExec will save the adversary time from writing their own tooling.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: A free alternative they can wrap up within their own malware is a much easier option in this instance.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Conclusion During destructive attacks like this there often has to be a thought given to the nature of the attack.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Disruption is the clear objective in this type of attack and it leaves us confident in thinking that the actors behind this were after embarrassment of the Olympic committee during the opening ceremony.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Disruption of services included the Olympic website being offline, meaning individuals could not print their tickets.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The opening ceremony reporting was degraded due to WiFi failing for reporters on site.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: The malware delivery mechanism is currently unknown which means the infection vector could be a multitude of options, but, if the attacker already had access to the environment, this attack could have been carried out remotely.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: This would allow the actors to specifically pinpoint the moment of the opening ceremony and would allow them to control their time of impact.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Coverage Additional ways our customers can detect and block this threat are listed below.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Advanced Malware Protection (AMP) is ideally suited to prevent the execution of the malware used by these threat actors.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: CWS or WSA web scanning prevents access to malicious websites and detects malware used in these attacks.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Email Security can block malicious emails sent by threat actors as part of their campaign.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Network Security appliances such asNGFW,NGIPS, andMeraki MX can detect malicious activity associated with this threat.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: AMP Threat Grid helps identify malicious binaries and build protection into all Cisco Security products.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Umbrella, our secure internet gateway (SIG), blocks users from connecting to malicious domains, IPs, and URLs, whether users are on or off the corporate network.
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text: Open Source Snort Subscriber Rule Set customers can stay up to date by downloading the latest rule pack available for purchase on Snort.org.IOCs Olympic Destroyer: edb1ff2521fb4bf748111f92786d260d40407a2e8463dcd24bb09f908ee13eb9Browser Stealer: 19ab44a1343db19741b0e0b06bacce55990b6c8f789815daaf3476e0cc30ebea (unpacked: ab5bf79274b6583a00be203256a4eacfa30a37bc889b5493da9456e2d5885c7f )
source: Olympic Destroyer Takes Aim At Winter Olympics.html

text:
System Stealer: f188abc33d351c2254d794b525c5a8b79ea78acd3050cd8d27d3ecfc568c2936 (unpacked a7d6dcdf5ca2c426cc6c447cff76834d97bc1fdff2cd14bad0b7c2817408c334 )Destroyer: ae9a4e244a9b3c77d489dee8aeaf35a7c3ba31b210e76d81ef2e91790f052c85Psexec (legit): 3337e3875b05e0bfba69ab926532e3f179e8cfbf162ebb60ce58a0281437a7efAdditional Olympic Destroyer:D934CB8D0EADB93F8A57A9B8853C5DB218D5DB78C16A35F374E413884D915016 EDB1FF2521FB4BF748111F92786D260D40407A2E8463DCD24BB09F908EE13EB9 3E27B6B287F0B9F7E85BFE18901D961110AE969D58B44AF15B1D75BE749022C2 28858CC6E05225F7D156D1C6A21ED11188777FA0A752CB7B56038D79A88627CC

text: Gives BackNoteholder and Preferred Shareholder DocumentsMobile Footer SectionSee what’s new at MandiantGet startedIncident Response HelpContact SalesSupportSign InCreate a Free Mandiant Advantage AccountTop Incident Response Contact sales Support Advantage Free Trial  BlogSupportContact usreport_problemIncident Response Assistance    Breadcrumb Home Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks   Threat Research Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority AttacksJohn Hultquist Jan 07, 20165 min read |    Last updated: Aug 23, 2022   Update 1.11.16 - SANS ICS Team Connects DotsUpdating the blog entry to bring attention to the recent analysis published by Mike Assante from the SANS ICS team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: "After analyzing the information that has been made available by affected power companies, researchers, and the media it is clear that cyber attacks were directly responsible for power outages in Ukraine.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: The SANS ICS team has been coordinating ongoing discussions and providing analysis across multiple international community members and companies.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We assess with high confidence based on company statements, media reports, and first-hand analysis that the incident was due to a coordinated intentional attack.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: "Read the full SANS post here - and see below for iSIGHTiSIGHT Partners Analyst CommentThe SANS ICS blog confirms conclusions previously reached by iSIGHT regarding the nature of the Ukrainian attacks (specifically the role of destructive malware and phone disruption) and attribution to Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: iSIGHT Partners believes this incident is a milestone because it is the first major cyber attack to substantially affect the civilian population and because of the overwhelming importance of the grid to multiple reliant sectors.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, Sandworm Team's previous interest in US and European critical systems underscores the threat they pose (see below for more on Sandworm Team.)Sandworm Team - Historical Targeting of Ukraine and Interest in SCADA SystemsSince last week, iSIGHT Partners has worked to provide details on the power outage in Ukraine to our global customers.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We have analyzed the forensic evidence we have been able to obtain from the region, contextualizing it within our knowledge of cyber espionage actors.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Many details of the event remain unknown, and given the nature of the incident, especially the use of destructive malware, we do not anticipate every detail will be exposed.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: However, we have linked Sandworm Team to the incident, principally based on BlackEnergy 3, the malware that has become their calling card.iSiGHT
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Partners has tracked Sandworm Team for some time - and we publicly reported on some of their activities in October 2014, when we discovered their use of a zero-day exploit, CVE-2014-4114.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: In that campaign, we saw targeting of Ukrainian government officials, members of the EU and NATO.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Shortly after releasing information on their espionage operations, our friends at TrendMicro found evidence that the operators were not only conducting classic strategic espionage but targeting SCADA systems as well.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Evidence of this accumulated, and iSIGHT Partners released a follow-up blog were we assessed that activity was reconnaissance for attack - a preparation for cyber attack to be carried out in the long term.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: ICS-CERT released a separate advisory as well.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Sandworm Team Activity - Late 2014 to Current DaySandworm Team went to ground shortly after being exposed in October of 2014, and malware with Dune references (the genesis for the 'Sandworm' moniker) which we had previously used to track them disappeared entirely.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: However, the unique malware variant, BlackEnergy 3, reemerged in Ukraine early in 2015, where we had first found Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Throughout 2015 we saw increased intrusion activity using BlackEnergy 3.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We warned our clients of new features suggesting an increased focus on European targets - though verification of targets was not possible at the time.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Additionally, we warned our customers about the targeting of both media and regional power authorities in the Ukraine, sectors later affected by cyber attacks.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Some of this information was recently shared by the folks at ESET, who have also been following Sandworm Team very closely for quite some time.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: On the Ukrainian Power Authority IncidentsLast week iSIGHT's sources provided us with the same KillDisk malware published by Rob Lee of SANS and Dragos Security.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: As ESET has, we place this malware within the greater context of activity tied to BlackEnergy 3, which we believe is Sandworm Team.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We believe this KillDisk malware is related to the destructive malware leveraged during Ukrainian elections in October.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: At the time, CERT-UA connected that incident to BlackEnergy 3.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Symantec has since verified those claims.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Furthermore, iSIGHT's own sources indicate that BlackEnergy 3 malware was deployed on at least one of the Ukrainian power systems affected by KillDisk.iSIGHT Partners is still collecting information on the mechanics of the power outage and what role the KillDisk malware played in the greater event.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: We cannot confirm that the KillDisk malware caused the outage.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: It may have been used following steps to manipulate power in order to impede restoration efforts or operator visibility.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: It is noteworthy that technical support numbers associated with the power authorities were allegedly flooded with calls, which may have been an effort to further overwhelm responders.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: On their official website, the Ukrainian security service, SBU, made this claim.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: OutlookA cyber attack of this nature is a milestone -although a predictable one.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: The aggressive nature of Sandworm Team's previous activity in Europe and the United States exposed their interest in targeting critical systems and indicated preparation for cyber attack.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

text: Targeting of critical entities in Ukraine throughout 2015, during a time of war, further presaged a desire to disrupt infrastructure.
source: Sandworm Team and the Ukrainian Power Authority Attacks _ Mandiant.html

Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis: Petya / NotPetya Ransomware

June 28, 2017
24 min read
 

 









Share on:



Share on Twitter




Share on LinkedIn




Share on Facebook




Share on Reddit




Email this post



Copy Link

 



On June 27, public announcements were made about a large-scale campaign of ransomware attacks across Europe.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The ransomware impacted notable industries such as Maersk, the world’s largest container shipping company.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The initial infection vector appears to be the exploitation of a Ukrainian tax software called MEDoc.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample also spreads on the internal network via exploitation of the EternalBlue SMB vulnerability, PsExec, WMI, and Admin$ shares.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Technical Analysis

Compiled Time:
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Sun Jun 18 07:14:36 2017 UTC
PE Sections (5): Name       Size       MD5
                  .text      48,640     c5bd3bb710ae377938b17980692b785b
                  .rdata     34,304     46418e52b546c1f696eb8a524f18c56e

source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This sample was compiled recently (18 June 2017 at 07:14:36 UTC) and contains an expired digital signature signed by Microsoft.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This sample utilizes SysInternals PsExec v1.98 for remote execution, with the PsExec digital signature copied and applied to the malware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
SysInternals Digital Signature Found on Malware

Initial analysis suggests that the malware is a new variant of the Petya family of ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This recent sample follows the encryption and ransom note functionality seen in Petya samples.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: However, further analysis suggests otherwise, leading to industry concerns of actual attribution and naming, with the colloquial names given of “NotPetya” and “Schrodinger’s Petya.”
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: To understand this, let’s explore some of the more technical components of the ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware itself, a Windows DLL library, is typically saved to the local Windows folder as perfc.dat if it runs with SeDebugPrivilege permission.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If it does not have this privilege, it saves perfc.dat to the All Users application data directory (CSIDL_COMMON_APPDATA) which is resolved by Windows to either C:\ProgramData or “C:\Documents and Settings\All Users\Application Data”.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware must be executed with a direct call to its export of ordinal 1, seen as “#1” in the command line.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: There are various reasons why malware tends to use this style of execution, with the most common being to prevent execution within a sandbox.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: A call to the standard DLL export function simply exits.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Ransomware Data Encryption
Upon execution, the malware will begin to perform privilege checking to determine what permissions the running account has, primarily checking for the SeDebugPrivilege permission, as detailed later in User Rights Checking and Malware Logic.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Based upon these privileges the malware will encrypt the victim system in one of two methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If the running user has the SeDebugPrivilege permission, the malware will assume it has administrative privileges, it will then attempt to encrypt the drive using the known Petya code.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is performed by overwriting the Master Boot Record (MBR) of the hard drive (PhysicalDrive0) with malicious code that displays a fake “chkdsk.exe” partition repair screen as it encrypts the hard drive, shown below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is a technique that is known to exist in Petya, using nearly identical text and code.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is the reason why the malware was initially considered to be Petya upon dynamic analysis, although static analysis showed vastly different code for the remainder of the malware’s functionality.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
False CHKDSK Output from Malware MBR Code
MBR-based Ransom Note
Alternatively, if the user is not running with administrative privileges, as determined by a lack of SeDebugPrivilege, the malware will use a user-space encryption routine, which is a different routine from the one detailed above.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the malware is finished obtaining privileges on the system, it looks for specific processes running on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware authors use a proprietary XOR encryption routine to mask what process names they are looking for.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Carbon Black created a brute force routine to determine what those process names were:
 



Encrypted Value
AV Filename
AV Product


0x2E214B44
avp.exe

0x651B3005
NS.exe

0x6403527E
ccSvcHst.exe
Symantec




A global variable is modified if these process names are found running on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This global variable affects how the malware runs on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If none of these AV processes are found on the system and the malware obtains the required privileges, the credential stealer is dropped and executed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The presence of these AV’s on the system also affect if the malware runs PsExec, writes to the MBR, the type of encryption used, and if the anti-forensic log clearing is executed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Process Name Hashing Function
 
Depending on the return values from this routine and the values SeDebugPrivilege check, if the process context does not have SeDebugPrivilege permissions then the variant will employ a technique common in ransomware variants.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Where files’ data is loaded by using the FindFile and MapViewofFile APIs before encrypting the file’s data.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The file is encrypted in memory using AES encryption and then written to disk when the FlushViewOfFile is called.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the encryption routine completes, the sample will attempt to remove forensic artifacts of its activities by utilizing cmd.exe to run the command listed in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is done after performing additional operating system checks which include ensuring that the system is not version 5.1/5.2 (Windows XP) or 6.1 (Windows 7).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: wevtutil cl Setup & wevtutil cl System & wevtutil cl Security & wevtutil cl Application & fsutil usn deletejournal /D
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
%c:”



Anti-forensics Commands
The command will use the wevtutil command to clear (cl) the logs for the Setup, System, Security, and Application event logs.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: It then uses the fsutil command to delete (/D)
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: the USN change journal from the current drive (noted as %c character type).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Before the sample exits it will force a reboot of the infected system using one of three methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The method chosen is dependent upon the context of the process privileges, which are outlined in the table below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will schedule a reboot early in its execution but, depending on the user privileges, will attempt to force a reboot earlier.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Condition
Reboot Method


If SeShutDown 
and SeDebug
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
The malware will initiate a shutdown using the InitiateSystemShutdown() Api


If only SeDebug
The malware will initiate a shutdown using a call to NtDll.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
NtRaiseHardError() API


If not SeDebug
The malware will rely upon the previously created scheduled task (sctasks.exe) to restart (shutdown.exe) the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
System Shutdown Conditions
Delivery and Exploitation
While the initial attack vector of a patient zero is currently unknown, what is known is that the malware is propagated across local environments using several methods.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Like other recent malware the ransomware utilizes the highly effective EternalBlue exploit for Windows SMB vulnerabilities to copy itself to other systems and execute, which is detailed later in this post.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: In addition to the SMB exploit propagation method, the malware also attempts to establish default administrative network shares (Admin$) with a call to WNetAddConnection2() using a null username and password.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: By using null for these two values, the network connection is made using the current user’s credentials, which directly affect organizations with shared local administrator accounts.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Additionally, if the malware was somehow executed by a domain administrator, these connections would be made even without a shared local administrator account.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
An example of this additional lateral movement attempt is below:

Lateral Movement to Admin Shares
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If a connection is made to the remote system, the malware will create a copy of itself directly on the other system using standard CreateFile() and WriteFile() API routines.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The malware also has the ability to extract an embedded and compressed resource (resource 3) containing the SysInternals PsExec.exe utility.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The psexec.exe file is written to disk as dllhost.dat.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This utility is then used to execute this file on the remote system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
PsExec Remote Execution Command Line Construction
 
Failing that, the malware will then leverage the existing Windows WMI utility to execute the file on the remote system, which is displayed in the image below:
WMIC Remote Execution Command Line Construction
 
As noted earlier, upon initial execution the sample will check several system privileges to determine the appropriate execution path.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If the process has SeDebugPrivilege it will, among other things, access the physical drive (highlighted in red below) and then initiate a scan that will enumerate other systems on the domain (area highlighted in green in the image below).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The area highlighted in red below shows where a function (labeled here as filename_check) is called, where the sample will check to see if the file C:\Windows\perfc is present on the system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: If present, the process will exit, which is leading many to call this a “kill switch” in the ransomware.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This was most likely done to ensure that ransomware was not installed and executed twice on a system, much in the same way a mutex or a file lock (Linux based), is used to prevent multiple instances from running on a system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Code responsible for this process is shown below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Reinfection Check
 
The second function (labeled Check_access_and_physicaldisk_Modify) is responsible for attempting to access the physical disk, and then gather drive geometry about the disk itself.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will then make modifications to the MBR.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: After the alterations have completed the sample will remove forensic artifacts in the manner detailed in Table 1 above, and then shut down as described in Table 2 above.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

Privilege and Drive Access Checks Prior to Scanning
 
The function (highlighted in green in the image above) will gather system information and then enumerate the other systems on the domain.

Grabbing Local System Info and Enumerating Systems
 
SMB propagation 
As previously referenced, this sample is also capable of spreading through SMB kernel exploitation (MS17-010, commonly referred to as EternalBlue).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The function displayed in the image below shows the sample building the SMB header, which will be used in the exploitation process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Building Exploit’s SMB Header

The sample will then decode several strings used in the SMB phase of the  attack (which are displayed in a later table).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The area highlighted in red below shows the call to create the SMB packet.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The area, highlighted in green, shows where the sample will send SMB packets and then wait for a response from the targeted system.

SMB Packet Generation and Handling
 
The table below shows the strings that were decoded in the previous image.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

Decoded Strings used in SMB Exploitation
If the sample finds an exploitable system, it will perform in the same manner that existing ransomware acted by passing a shellcode payload to the target system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The function highlighted in the image below shows where the shellcode is first decoded with a simple XOR value of 0xCC.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Initial De-obfuscation of Shellcode Payload
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The image below shows a portion of the decoded shellcode, which contains additional layers of obfuscation and is still being analyzed.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Resource 4 (once inflated and decoded using a simple XOR of 0x86) is additional shell code that is used in the SMB exploitation process.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Continued De-obfuscation of Shellcode Payload
 
User Rights Checking and Effect on Malware Logic
This sample looks for three different types of privileges to perform its actions:

SeShutdownPrivilege
 – Required to shutdown the system
SeDebugPrivilege
 – A token field that allows the owning process to adjust the memory of other processes on the computer.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This is a very powerful privilege that allows the malware to perform near system level tasks.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
SeTcbPrivilege
 – This is another very powerful privilege that allows the owning process to act as part of the operating system.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Prior to any major function being executed, the malware attempts to gain any/all of the above privileges.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
The values are added together using Boolean OR commands which can result in the following results:

0
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
= No privileges granted
1 = SeShutdownPrivilege
2 = SeDebugPrivilege
3 = SeShutdownPrivilege/SeDebugPrivilege
4 = SeTcbPrivilege
5 = SeShutdownPrivilege/SeTcbPrivilege
6 = SeDebugPrivilege/SeTcbPrivilege
7 = All privileges

Based upon the overall values constructed from these checks, the malware will perform varying sets of routines.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Most notably are the methods for which to encrypt files on the system and in rebooting the system after infection.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Credential Harvesting
If the variant detects that its process is running with SeDebugPrivilege privileges it will call a function that is highlighted in red in the image below.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text:
Calling Credential Harvesters
 
The malware contains four separate, compressed resources that are used as additional commands to execute during operation.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This function will initially attempt to determine if the operating system is either x86 or 64-bit and then it will either load a password dumper from either Resource “1” or “2” (which ultimately are x86 and 64-bit executable files respectively).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: It should be noted that all of the four resources are stored as compressed buffers that can be inflated with zlib.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Each resource contains a DWORD value at offset 0 that is the length of the data once it is inflated.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Once the OS type has been determined and the appropriate resource loaded, the sample will write the executable to the system %TEMP% path with a OS-generated temporary file name (highlighted in red in the image below).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: The sample will then create a named pipe to the temporary file (highlighted in blue), and execute the file as a new process, with a parameter of the named pipe (highlighted in green).
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: This will allow the sample to get the results of the credential harvester.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html

text: Once completed the sample will delete the temporary file from the disk.
source: Carbon Black Threat Research Technical Analysis_ Petya _ NotPetya Ransomware – VMware Security Blog.html
